pullrequest.title: Update config file handling and 'yt hub_register/upload_notebook/hubstart'

content.raw: I thought about it. My first implementation even had `warnings.warn`. I'm also reluctant of removing users' files. However I settled on assumption that users shouldn't care/know where the config file is at all. Hence the `yt-config` implementation. I'm of course happy to implement it as you suggest. On the other hand, mpl did that this way and those warnings about `.matplotlibrc` vs `.config/matplotlib` were really annoying...
content.html: I thought about it. My first implementation even had warnings.warn. I'm also reluctant of removing users' files. However I settled on assumption that users shouldn't care/know where the config file is at all. Hence the yt-config implementation. I'm of course happy to implement it as you suggest. On the other hand, mpl did that this way and those warnings about .matplotlibrc vs .config/matplotlib were really annoying...

pullrequest.title: Update config file handling and 'yt hub_register/upload_notebook/hubstart'

content.raw:
OK, how about this - print a visible warning if both files exist? That way users will get feedback if they create a new .yt/config file after it's already been moved to the new location (because they don't know anything about the new location and missed the message you printed here).

BTW, the message here should definitely print out where the new location is.
content.html:
OK, how about this - print a visible warning if both files exist? That way users will get feedback if they create a new .yt/config file after it's already been moved to the new location (because they don't know anything about the new location and missed the message you printed here).

BTW, the message here should definitely print out where the new location is.

content.raw:
Can you create an issue to make a conda package for girder_client that we can make our yt conda package depend on?

Is girder_client a pure-python package? If so I'd probably be ok with just adding it as a hard dependency. Of course others on yt-dev might disagree.
content.html:
Can you create an issue to make a conda package for girder_client that we can make our yt conda package depend on?

Is girder_client a pure-python package? If so I'd probably be ok with just adding it as a hard dependency. Of course others on yt-dev might disagree.

content.raw:
I will manually test this this week but I've left a few comments below.

In addition, what do you think about adding the functionality of the `yt-config` entry point to the existing `yt` entry point as a new `yt config` subcommand? That way we don't need to teach people about the new executable or worry about distributing it.
content.html:
I will manually test this this week but I've left a few comments below.

In addition, what do you think about adding the functionality of the yt-config entry point to the existing yt entry point as a new yt config subcommand? That way we don't need to teach people about the new executable or worry about distributing it.

Maybe a screenshot or two would be helpful?

The workflow is a bit more complicated than this - you need to go to the settings view, click the "API keys" tab, click "generate an API key", fill out a form naming it and giving the API key access to your account.

Maybe a screenshot or two would be helpful?

pullrequest.title: Update config file handling and 'yt hub_register/upload_notebook/hubstart'

description:
This PR:

* updates th config file location in accordance to the [XDG Base Directory Specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html)
* performs an automatic migration of the old config file if the new one doesn't exist
* add a simple command line tool `yt-config` for config file editing
* updates `hub_register` and `upload_notebook` subcommands to work with Girder
* changes default value of `hub_url` to `https://girder.hub.yt`
* updates `setup.py` to include extra dependencies for interacting with hub
* reimplement `yt hubstart`, obsoletes PR 1444
* Convert `yt-config` to yt's subparser
* Move hub commands to separate subparser
* Autogenerate `command -h` blocks in the documentation
* addressed Andrew's comments
